awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Integrated Control of Fidelity and Real-Time Performance in Networked Sensing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Networked Sensing Systems (NSSs) interact with the physical world by tightly integrating sensing, computation, networking, and physical processes. NSS systems are being deployed for numerous critical applications such as security, civil infrastructure, healthcare, manufacturing, and transportation. These applications often impose stringent performance requirements. Many computation and communication tasks of NSS systems must be finished within certain timing constraints to avoid undesirable or even catastrophic consequences -- a property known as real-time assurance. In addition, mission-critical NSS systems must maintain their performance at an acceptable level even when noises and errors occur in input and/or internal system components -- a property known as fidelity. This research is to design a novel NSS control framework that integrates data fusion, calibration, and real-time performance control into a solution that balances requirements for fidelity and real-time assurance. The expected outcomes include: 1) a unified multi-tier performance control framework for both fidelity and real-time assurance; 2) improvements in fidelity assurance through novel model and fusion calibration algorithms; 3) a fidelity-aware real-time performance control mechanism; and 4) integrated fidelity and real-time assurance for several mission-critical domains including real-time volcano monitoring and tomography, and high-fidelity ad hoc surveillance. 

This project has broad implications for future NSS systems in multiple application domains that require high-fidelity processing of dynamic and complex physical information within stringent timeliness constraints. Educational and outreach activities include introduction of NSS systems into two new graduate courses with software, testbed, and labs developed in the course of this project, and recruitment of women and minority students for participation in the project.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to design a novel control framework that integrates data fusion, calibration, and real-time performance control into a unified solution for fidelity and real-time assurance of networked sensing systems (NSS). This is a collaborative project with Michigan State University. On the Ohio State University (OSU) side, the main intellectual merits include: 1) A fidelity-aware real-time performance control mechanism, and 2) Integrated fidelity and real-time assurance for important applications, such as thermal monitoring for large-scale data centers.

We now introduce our technical outcomes in detail. For fidelity-aware real-time control in NSS, we have conducted two research activities. First, in order to ensure real-time communication for an NSS with multiple data flows under end-to-end delay constraints, as well as minimized transmission power consumption, we have designed an optimization algorithm to configure the transmission power level for every node and assign overlapping channels to different data flows. Second, we have designed DutyCon, a control theory-based dynamic duty cycle control approach for real-time communications in networked sensing systems. The most important feature of DutyCon is that it decomposes the end-to-end delay guarantee problem in an NSS into a set of single-hop delay guarantee problems along each data flow in the network. The results of those research studies were published in ACM Transactions on Sensor Networks (ToSN) in March and July 2013, respectively.

For data center thermal monitoring and management with high fidelity, we have conducted four research activities. First, we have proposed a model-based approach that leverages sensor placement for precise overheating server component detection in NSS. We have adopted Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to establish the thermal model and analyze the thermal status of the server enclosure under various overheating conditions, such as inlet overheating, fan failures and CPU overloading. Second, we have designed a high-fidelity real-time predictive thermal and energy control system that improves the energy efficiency of the cooling systems of a data center, while meeting a set of thermal safety requirements. Our system leverages the server built-in sensors and monitoring utilities, as well as an external easy-to-deploy wireless sensor network to monitor both the cyber and physical status of a data center, which includes CPU utilization, dynamic air flow, temperature distribution, and CRAC/fan settings. Third, most of today’s data centers are equipped with servers that rely on air cooling, which is well known to have low cooling efficiency due to undesired air recirculation. As a result, data centers have recently started to consider liquid-cooled servers for improved cooling efficiency. To this end, we have proposed an intelligent placement algorithm that deploys liquid-cooled servers to minimize the power consumption of the data center cooling system with a high fidelity. Finally, we have integrated a new emerging cooling technique, free air cooling, into our cooling power optimization framework and investigated how to leverage different cooling techniques for high energy efficiency and fidelity. The results of those research studies were published in IGCC 2014, RTSS 2014, ToSN 2015, and the Elsevier Journal of Sustainable Computing in 2013 and 2016, respectively.

The broader impacts of this project are as follows. First, our fidelity and real-time control framework has significantly improved the real-time performance and energy efficiency of NSS systems with a high fidelity assurance. For example, our work published in IGCC 2014 demonstrates that our framework achieves 26.7% less total power consumption with dynamically guaranteed application real-time performance and fidelity. Those timely solutions can significantly help the NSS and data center designers to achieve better performance with lower energy consumption. Second, in sharp contrast to existing work based on simplistic physical models, a key advantage of our framework is its reliance on rigorous and efficient CFD analysis as a theoretical foundation to capture the thermal dynamics of a data center in various overheating scenarios. We then design online detection and prediction algorithms based on the offline CFD analysis. This novel design methodology has made impacts to other disciplines such as mechanical engineering by identifying NSS as a possible new application field for advanced thermal fluid dynamic analysis. Finally, on the education side, we have successfully integrated our research results into several undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the PI, such as ECE 8862, Special Topics in Advanced Computer Design Methodologies. The research of this project has provided a rich set of examples, design tools, and project opportunities for these courses. In addition, we have supported one Ph.D. student to do dissertations on this topic. The student has been trained with CFD and optimization designs and analysis for computer systems. On the result dissemination, we have presented our results in major conferences and workshops. We have also released all the software artifacts developed in this project (including optimization algorithms, simulators, and related tools) in the open-source model.
